Award.AwardTitle: North Carolina Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The NCLSAMP project proposes to utilize "promising practices" as well as new program initiatives to achieve the following goals: 1) Increase the pool of competent underrepresented graduates with STEM bachelor's degrees; 2) Promote retention and baccalaureate degree attainment in STEM academic programs, and; 3) Increase the number of students who matriculate into STEM graduate programs.

Phase V (Senior-level) NCLSAMP expected outcomes at the end of the project are:
1. An overall average of seventy-five percent (75%) of NCLSAMP participants will be retained in STEM baccalaureate programs within the Alliance.
2. The pool of competent underrepresented graduates with STEM bachelor's degrees will have increased by 10%.
3. The number of NCLSAMP participants who matriculate into STEM graduate programs will have increased by 10%.

Building upon its successes in the implementation of cohort-based learning, collaborative instructional approaches and block-scheduling, the Alliance will help its members institutionalize and maintain high impact practices engaging a larger population of underrepresented students into STEM-learning communities. Best practices that will continue and expand based on Phase I experience include Facilitated Study Groups, Research Skills Development Workshops, and Mentored Research Experiences for Undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Established in 1993, the North Carolina Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (NC-LSAMP) is made up of eight universities: North Carolina A&T State University (Lead), Fayetteville State University, North Carolina Central University, North Carolina State University, University of North Carolina Chapel Hill, University of North Carolina Charlotte, University of North Carolina Pembroke, and Winston-Salem State University. During Phase V partner institutions sought to increase both the number of underrepresented minority (URM) students enrolled in STEM majors and earned STEM BS degrees. Specifically, the alliance articulated the following outcomes: seventy-five percent of NC-LSAMP participants would be retained in STEM majors; the pool of competent underrepresented graduates with STEM bachelor's degrees and NC-LSAMP participants who matriculate into STEM graduate programs will have increased by 10%.  

To achieve these goals partner institutions implemented faculty mentored research experiences for undergraduates (REUs) academic and professional development workshops, and student support initiatives. Across the alliance, NC-LSAMP partners provided opportunities for URM students to participate in faculty mentored undergraduate research. Research included campus faculty mentored research as well as research opportunities provided by external partners. As a result of collaboration with researchers beyond our campuses, NC-LSAMP scholars conducted research with the Native America and Pacific Islanders Research Experience (NAPIRE), the Organization for Tropical Studies, and the Summer International Research Experiences (IRES) in China sponsored by the HBCU-UP ACE DSA Program. NC-LSAMP Scholars also participated in research sponsored by national laboratories including Argonne, Brookhaven, Livermore and Oakridge.

Partners also offered programmatic initiatives designed to support the development of STEM academic and professional development skills.  Initiatives included summer bridge and transition programs, residential learning communities, and peer and faculty mentoring. In addition, workshops were held to support students' academic and professional development.  Each year the alliance held its NC-LSAMP Research Conference hosted by an alliance partner. Students and faculty from across the alliance attended. The format for the conferences included guest speakers and workshops, with the highlight being student research presentations. By participating in the conference, many students presented research for the first time, which provided an opportunity to share their research with a broad audience.

NC-LSAMP  Research Scholars also attended and presented at local and national conferences including the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABCRUMS), Minorities in Agriculture, Natural Resources and Related Sciences (MANNRS), Women of Color in STEM Conference, American Society of Engineering Education Southeastern Section Conference, the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) International ME Conference, and the State of North Carolina Undergraduate Research and Creativity Symposium (SNCURS). NC-LSAMP scholars have also been recipients of competitive national scholarships and fellowships, including the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, Mitchel Scholarship, Barry Goldwater Scholarship, and the Fulbright Fellowship.

As a result of implementation of a broad array of student academic, personal and professional development initiatives, the North Carolina Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation achieved the following outcomes: underrepresented minority student STEM enrollment across the alliance increased by 21% and STEM degrees conferred to URM students increased by 53%.  In addition, 85% of NC-LSAMP participants were retained in STEM majors and 20% of funded LSAMP scholars enrolled in STEM graduate degree programs.
